009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
012import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * This (abstract) class represents a filter which treats all pixel values as scalars. If the processed image has more
017 * than one component (e.g., a RGB color image), this filter is automatically and independently applied to all
018 * (scalar-valued) components. The filter calls the method {@code doPixel(PixelSlice, int, int)} for each image pixel,
019 * which must be implemented by any concrete sub-class.
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * Thus a custom filter based on this class only needs to specify the steps to be performed for a single pixel. The
023 * remaining filter mechanics including multiple components, out-of-bounds coordinate handling, multiple passes and data
024 * copying are handled by this class and its super-class (see {@link GenericFilter}).
025 * </p>
026 */
027public abstract class GenericFilterScalar extends GenericFilter {
028        
029        // for progress reporting only
030        private int slice;
031        private int sliceMax = 1;
032        
033        private int iter;
034        private int iterMax = 1;
035        
036        // apply filter to a stack of pixel slices (1 pass)
037        @Override
038        protected void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
039                sliceMax = source.getDepth();
040                for (int k = 0; k < sliceMax; k++) {
041                        //IJ.log("+++++++ starting slice " + k);
042                        this.slice = k;
043                        runSlice(source.getSlice(k), target.getSlice(k));       // default behavior: apply filter to each plane, place results in target
044                }
045        }
046        
047        // a bit wasteful, as we provide a separate target for each plane
048        private void runSlice(PixelSlice sourcePlane, PixelSlice targetPlane) {
049                final int width = sourcePlane.getWidth();
050                final int height = sourcePlane.getHeight();
051                this.iterMax = width * height;
052                this.iter = 0;
053                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
054                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
055                                targetPlane.setVal(u, v, doPixel(sourcePlane, u, v));
056                                this.iter++;
057                        }
058                }
059                this.iter = 0;
060        }
061
062        // this method every scalar filter must implement
063        // calculate the result value for a single pixel
064
065        /**
066         * This method defines the steps to be performed for a single image pixel and must be implemented by any concrete
067         * sub-class. The source data are passed as a {@link PixelSlice} container, which holds the scalar values of one
068         * image component. The method {@link PixelSlice#getVal(int, int)} should be used to read individual pixel values.
069         * These data should not be modified but the (float) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
070         *
071         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
072         * @param u the current x-position
073         * @param v the current y-position
074         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
075         */
076        protected abstract float doPixel(PixelSlice source, int u, int v);
077        
078        // -------------------------------------------------------------------
079
080        @Override
081        protected final double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
082                double loopProgress = (this.iter + subProgress) / this.iterMax;
083                //IJ.log("   loopProgress = " + loopProgress);
084                double sliceProgress = (this.slice + loopProgress) / this.sliceMax;
085                //IJ.log("   sliceProgress = " + sliceProgress);
086                //System.out.println("reportProgress: GenericFilterScalar " + localProgress);
087                return super.reportProgress(sliceProgress);
088        }
089
090}
